Page.title: Federal Income and the GDP
Page.description: The United States collected $3.4 trillion in 2017, 17% of the GDP.
Page._content:
In 2017, the government collected $3.3 trillion

Most of the federal government's income comes from federal taxes.

Taxes from individuals and small businesses make up a little less than half of all federal income. Besides income taxes, federal revenue comes from payroll taxes which are taken out of your paycheck to help fund programs such as Social Security, Medicare, and Unemployment Insurance. Also, corporations pay taxes as part of doing business in the United States.

The remaining sources of government income consist of excise, estate, and other taxes and fees.

How does the amount of federal income compare to the size of the economy?

In Fiscal Year 2017, the total GDP of the U.S. was $19.5 trillion.

The government collected the equivalent of 17% of GDP.

What's GDP?

What are the sources of government income?

Continue

$3.3 trillion divided by the U.S. population in 2017 (326.4 million U.S. Census Bureau*), is equivalent to a little more than $10,000 for every individual.

Gross Domestic Product (GDP) measures the size of the nation's economy in terms of the total value of goods and services that are produced in a year. Measuring the money collected by the government relative to GDP is a helpful indicator of the economy's capacity to sustain the programs the government provides for the people and the government's success in helping the economy grow.
Page.raw:

Page.title: Federal Income Categories
Page.description: This is the text that goes in the meta description tag
Page._content:
Here's how $3.3 trillion breaks down.

Income by Source Categories

Click to dive deeper into income

The $3.3 trillion the government collected last year keeps the federal government in operation.

The majority of government income collected comes from individual taxpayers and small businesses. The second largest category comes from those taxes that come directly from your paycheck. These taxes support programs such as Social Security, Medicare, and Unemployment compensation.

Other sources of income include revenue collected from excise taxes, estate taxes, and customs duties. Government income also comes from payments made to federal agencies like the Post Office who sell products or services to the public, like stamps.

We encourage you to explore the bar chart below. It breaks down the various federal government income categories both in total dollars as well as by percent of income. What makes up individual income taxes? What exactly makes up Employment and General Retirement? What makes up the 12% of federal income that doesn’t come from individuals or corporations?

Have you visited a national park recently?

How does the amount of federal income compare to the size of the economy?

Click the chart to dive deeper into the various sources of government income, including additional income sources outside of federal taxes.

How has government income changed over time?

Next we will explore, trends in federal income over the past 5 years.

Continue

$3.3 trillion divided by the U.S. population in 2017 (326.4 million U.S. Census Bureau*), is equivalent to a little more than $10,000 for every individual.

All data is representative of FY 2017 and provided by the Bureau of the Fiscal Service and Department of the Treasury.

Page.title: Trends in Federal Income Categories
Page.description: This is the text that goes in the meta description tag
Page._content:
Federal Income Trends Over Time From 2013 – 2017

The chart below displays trends in government income over time.

Have you been paying more taxes? Not necessarily. What this chart is showing is the various relationships between federal income categories and those revenue sources over time. While some categories have seen an increase in revenue, others have remained steady or dropped.

Explore for yourself!

Click the chart below to see how changes in subcategories have influenced the overall trend of income by source over the past five years.

Come on. Click that button.

You know you want to.

Continue

Income over Time by Source Categories

Click an income category to view more
All data is representative of FY 2017and provided by the Bureau of the Fiscal Service and Department of the Treasury.
Income for prior years adjusted for inflation

Page.title: Federal Income Country Comparison
Page.description: This is the text that goes in the meta description tag
Page._content:
Compare the income of the United States to other countries.

The chart below shows income collected by the U.S. government compared to 171 other countries in 2017.

As we previously learned the $3.3 trillion in income that was collected was equivalent to 17.4% of the total GDP of the United States, which as $19.5 trillion.

Relative in size, the United States collected the most out of any country and has one of the highest GDP. But in comparison, government income as a comparison to GDP was only a small portion.

How does the U.S. compare to other countries? We encourage you to check out the chart below to see for yourself. You can compare total income to other countries vs. income as a percent of GDP. What changes do you see? How does the U.S. match up to countries of similar economic size and population? Pick a country of interest or curiosity and compare for yourself.

Country Comparison

You can sort this list in a variety of ways. Click the sort button to adjust.
All data is representative of FY 2017. Data provided by
